results.notes: Several specimens scattered among specimens of Cantharellus lateritius in a 12’ X 20’ (approximate) open area in Oak-Hickory woods. To quote Kuo (referenced this ob.), “Cantharellus confluens, found in the southeastern Midwest, is nearly identical [to Cantharellus lateritious] but features a stem that gives rise to several confluent caps.” I know there is controversy regarding whether this is a separate species or not, but I don’t know if anyone has published a paper yet citing DNA evidence to provide a definitive answer. For now this may remain fodder for splitters vs lumpers discussions.

results.notes:
Amanita brunnescens G.F. Atk., Amanitaceae, Agaricales.
Brown grisette = поплавок коричневый = толкачик коричневый.
Brown fragile mushroom.
Cap: 4-10cm, bell-shaped, smooth, convex up to almost flat, sometimes with a small wide central knob, margin radially grooved, because skin is transparent; colour changed from light brown up to grayish-brown; sometimes with concentric colouring. Young cap shape between oval and cone and it often has irregular coloured whitish with brown or orange spots and edges remnant of veil at the top. Flesh is white.
Gills: free, close to almost distant, white up to dull brown. Odour is weak and pleasant.
Stalk: 8-16cm long, 0.6-2.5cm thick, enlarged weakly down; brownish-white up to dull grayish-brown when old. Lower part of stalk has a sag-like whitish veil.
Habitat: small group scattered in pine-tree forest with rare birches in dry places or along edge in meadows, sometimes near birches among pine-trees.
Mushroom is edible as light-yellow and light-gray kinds.
Season: June-August.

Suillus luteus (L.) Roussel, Boletaceae, Agaricales. (Slippery Jack or Маслёнок поздний)
Cap: 5-10cm convex up to flattened; slimy in wet weather up to glossy in dry period; brown to yellow-brown, minor reddish-brown or brownish-white (very young). Odour is fragrant. Flesh is white up to light yellow for old unit. Tubes: attached, colour from yellowish-white up to yellow. Stalk: 3-7cm long, white up to light-yellow; 1.5-3cm thick, enlarged down.
Veil: white complete unbroken pellicle at young unit then broke fragments up to purplish-drab sleeve-like ring when old.
Habitat: do not like hot weather, scattered to abundant in pine-tree forest with rare birches. Edibility: good (several methods of cooking).
Season: June – October (when wet chill summer) or September – October (hot dry summer

Code: Bot_984/2016_DSC3464

Habitat: grassy yard of a farmhouse, open place; almost flat terrain, calcareous, skeletal ground; partly in shade; partly protected from direct rain by the trough, average precipitation ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 570 m (1.870 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: eleven years old, handmade wooden water trough (Larix decidua wood), standing on four thin wooden legs; wood still (almost) intact, the trough still capable to hold water.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, next to Trenta 2, Skokar (abandoned) farm house, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Spore dimensions and type of surface, size and color of the sporocarps, small meshed, persistent peridial net, sparsely branched internal capillitium with extensions, wavy columella toward its end, columella reaching the apex of the sporocarps, as well as habitus and substratum fit well to the description of Stemonitis lignicola in the literature.

Sporocarps 8.2-8.5 mm high, stalks 2- 2.1 mm long. Spore print abundant, dark brown.

What I am curious is, did the whole development process of this myxomicete from start to the end take place on the water trough (which is most of the time dry and standing in free air), or did this thing really climb up one of the thin trough’s legs in the form of plasmodium before building sporocarps?

Herbarium: Mycotheca and lichen herbarium (LJU-Li) of Slovenian Forestry Institute, Večna pot 2, Ljubljana, Index Herbariorum LJF

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

This is a revisitation of the place of Observation 210183, which is by far the site where I found the bigger population of Lobaria amplisima, always accompanied with Dendriscocaulon umhausense. This population seems to be healthy and in development at the tree where all the observation took place. Closer (about 1 meter to one side and 5 meters to the other side) there are two other tree of the same species and of about the same age and a group of 5-6 younger trees at about 10 meters. None have any (even small) specimen, as far as I could see. It should be also mentioned that at one of the closer oak trees Dendriscocaulon umhausense apppears associated with Physconia, a feature that I already reported in previous observations (see Observation 244856).

results.notes: this is the most common form of the many subvelutipes types I collect. All parts bruise blue, colbalt blue in the flesh and dark blue everywhere else. the pores are deep red aging to dark red, tiny (2-3/mm), round (see photo) and bruise almost black. The tubes are yellow and shallow (3mm) in this collection of young fruitbodies. Cap is velvety brown to fuzzy olive brown with hints of dark red at the edges. Under 10X the cap shows matted short brown hairs throughout. The stipe has a ground color of pale yellow barely visable because of the dense overlay of matted red scurfy material. The cut flesh is bright yellow, quickly turing colbalt blue and then fading the flesh to a dull cream color in the cap and dull yellow in the stipe. KOH on flesh is orange changing to amber red over time. KOH on cap dark cherry red. KOH on stipe orange. NH4OH on stipe yellowish turning amber over time. Cap size 5-7 CM X 2.0-22CM. Stipe 4-7 CM long, 2CM wide. Habitat is oak/beech/birch forest along a path. These have been saved for further study.

Inocybe sororia Kauffman
Cap: 3-6 cm wide, oval or conical, then bell-shaped or convex with a knob up to almost flat with sharp knob; dull yellow minor lemon-yellow and knob is darker and brownish-yellow; margin upturning or radial split when old; surface fibrous and radial lined with tiny cracks.
Gills: attached with notched edge (pinching out end), whitish or light cream or some pinkish up to reddish-brown when old, close and narrow up to moderately broad with short and very short additional gills, often with reddish-brown tiny spots.
Stalk: 5-9 cm long, 0.5-1.2cm thick, slightly enlarged down, whitish and fine silky up to brownish-white then reddish-brown or brown when old, fibrous and hollow.
Edibility: poisonous.
Habitat: single or scattered small groups in pine-tree forest with some birches
Season: July-August

A solitary specimen in grass under Pin Oak. Cap: 8.5 cm., smooth, dry, finely reticulate; pale yellow pores which darken to yellow within 30 minutes and finally to dingy yellow overnight. Stem: 5 cm X 1.5 cm., very small amount of pinkish-brown reticulation at apex. White mycelium at base. Flesh bruised pinkish-brown when sliced. No reaction to KOH. results.notes: I’m re-posting this old ob from 2011. Maybe there’s something to be learned here. Back then I vacillated between subvelutipes and subluridellus. In 2011 I chose subvelutipes. Now I think differently and choose subluridellus. Here’s my reasoning: In 2011 I mistakenly thought there was a contradiction in the macro-chemical tests for the two but there isn’t, at least not with the tests I do with KOH and NH4OH. I didn’t do microscopy. That leaves macro descriptions. rereading the descriptions in all my sources I found- subvelutipes has a stipe that’s red and yellow. These have yellow stipes. if you think you see red on the stipe I’m going to suggest that’s a bruise. there are no “stiff red hairs” at the base. These IS some matted yellow basal mycelium! This is a quote from Smith’s description of the stipe of subluridellus. “…thick, solid, equal,pale lemon-yellow, ….red in the base, especially in the cortex, surface coated over the base with a thin coating of appressed sulfur-colored hyphae.” My field notes from this collection are not much help but I did note at the time that this seemed to be one of at least three distinct forms of what we were calling subvelutipes back in 2011. The above are my resons for voting subluridellus. Now I leave it to the zen masters of facebook to have at it.

Stephens State Park is in North Jersey, and that part of the state has been dry for months, but nonetheless some boletes made an appearance following some rain earlier in July.
The posted trio of fruiting bodies (likely three separate collections labeled as “A”, “B” and “C” in the attached photos) was the freshest among a sizable collection of yellow-brown mature and post mature boletes with bluing yellow pores that defied identification (no one wanted to work on them!). Yet, their colors have been blunted by the heat and dryness, too. None have any red or pink in their stipes. The odor and staining of the exposed context made tentative identification possible.
The dramatic and instant bluing of Collections “B” and “C” followed by a relatively quick change over to red-brown on the bruised/cut context, tubes and pores appears to be a hallmark of L. pseudosensibilis (this was pointed out by Gary Lincoff at the 2015 COMA foray). Both collections also had the same unpleasant fish-like odor. Note the thin tube layer, which is consistent with genus Lanmaoa.
However, Collection “A” looked different from the other two with its richer reddish-brown cap and darker yellow pores. The exposed flesh blued too, but the bluing was weak and patchy, transitioned to a dingy brownish gray color and dissipated over time; it smelled more like beef bouillon. Thus I am less sure about it being L. pseudosensibilis.

Whitish fragile mushroom with free gills, a cottony stalk and a silky cap.
Cap: 35-75 mm, white, smooth and silky, cone or bell-shaped when young, then convex, broadly convex with indistinct wide yellowish knob; small remnants of veil along margin.
Flesh is white and fragile.
Gills: close, free, moderately broad minor narrow, white up to yellowish-white or dull cream when died.

Cap: 6-15cm wide, bell-shaped or “square head”, then convex, broadly convex up to almost flattened; white, minor yellowish-white (very old cap brownish-white), bruising weak and irregular light yellow; smooth, sometimes slightly scaly or concentric scaly when old; young cap bottom is covered with white veil, later cap margin often has small hanging veil remnants.
Gills: free, very close, narrow then moderately broad or broad when old; color from white or cream-white when covered with veil, then light pink, brownish-pink, purplish-brown up to purplish-black when old.
Veil: partial veil white (young), leaving wide flaring up to pendant ring.
Stalk: 8-16cm long, white up to yellowish-white, bruising light yellow then light brown; 1.5-3cm thick, slightly enlarging down, sometimes with indistinct basal bulb; sometimes hollow and fine fibrous with edging. Partial veil leaves a ring at upper part of stalk.
Edibility: good.
Habitat: small groups or single scattered on ground with grass or pine needles after hard rains in pine-tree forest or edges and meadows.
Season: May – September.

Lycoperdon perlatum Pers. Lycoperdaceae, Lycoperdales. (Gem-studded Puffball or Головач шиповатый настоящий или дождевик перламутровый.)
Fleshy whitish soft mushroom with very fine conical spines, cap and stalk make a solid body.
Mushroom: 3-6cm wide, 3-6 cm high, wide pear-shaped with elongated base as a false stalk, turban-shaped top with a stalk covered with very tiny short spines (when adult), at first it covered with irregular shape granules and pyramids as a coarse powder; whitish, often with weak cream coloring (or very light coffee with milk); cap and stalk compose a single body; young flesh is white, then greenish-yellow up to greenish-brown spore powder as dry dust. A small 3-6mm hole appears at the top finally. Old mushroom is keeping pear-like shape and colored in olive or light brown minor brown.
Habitat: common kind; crowded small clusters (minor single unite) up to very abundant in pine-tree forest minor along forest in grassy area. This kind under trees is usually slightly colored in very light brown tints.
Edibility: edible and delicious when young and flesh is white.
Season: June-August.

Description on the drawing is in Dutch, so here’s the English translation with additional information:

Pileus:
Up to 25mm diameter, plano-convex with very weak broad umbo, slightly greasy, finely rugulose, dries up from center towards margin, margin striate, golden yellow to greenish/lemon yellow, darker in center.

Lamellae:
L: 40, l: 3; whitish at first, later dull pink, margin equal and smooth, very narrowly attached.

Stipe:
Up to 2,5x the diameter of the cap, finely striate across the whole length, whitish to slightly pale brownish, hollow, flattened at the apex, flexuous, pale to white base, looks somewhat bulbous.

Context:
Whitish throughout, slightly yellower in the cap

Taste/smell:
Taste is slightly mushroomy, not really much to it; smell again slightly mushroomy.

Micro:
Spores asymmetrically globose with small apiculus and droplets in them, pileocystidia are globose as well.

Ecology:
On well decayed parts of a broadleaf log, sandy, fairly moist soil, quite eutrophic area.

results.notes: In moss in Mixed woods. Oak, Maple, Yellow Birch, White Pine, Hemlock. White latex no change in the field, taste mild, no discernible odor. No spore print obtained.

Description:

Pileus:
50 mm diameter, campanulate eventually near flat with umbo, plicate, brownish grey center, grey outer half, very little filamentose velum, thin context.

Lamellae:
Free from stipe, regular distance, greyish, later grey black, semi-deliquescent.

Stipe:
120×3-7mm, broader directly under the cap, floccose, wooly foot, hollow, white.

Micro:
Dark red brown, ellipsoid spores, slightly truncate, very small but clearly visible apiculus; basidia 4-sterigmate; long chains of elongated, hyaline, partially encrusted velum cells on the cap.

Ecology:
In deciduous woods, mainly Fagus, Quercus, Tilia and Alnus. On thick layer of yet to decay leaf litter.

Description

Pileus:
49mm diameter, irregular convex, appressed felty, finely cracked margin showing pink context, dull vinaceous pink on margin, with greenish yellow hues in the center, slow blue bruising.

Pores:
Large, greenish yellow, irregular, fairly fast bruising; tubes 7mm long, greenish yellow (concolourous with pores), sinuate, slow bruising.

Stipe:
7-10mm, tapering towards apex, compressed, flexuous, fibrous, dry surface, dull red fibrils covering entire stipe, yellow context is visible through the fibrils, short tapering foot with yellow basal mycelium, firm, weak bruising, pores running over the yellow apex.

Context:
Pale yellow in cap, slow bruising after cutting; brighter yellow in stipe, sericeous, mottled, slow bruising after cutting, few orange red dots in the base.

Micro:
Almost fusiform to slender ellipsoid spores, one or some droplets, apiculate; quite long and irregular pleurocystidia.

Ecology:
Solitary, in mesotrophic grassy lawn on sandy soil, associated with young Betula.

Amanita umbrinolutea (Secr. ex Gillet) Bataille
Brown grisette, поплавок коричневый или толкачик.
Brown fragile mushroom.
Cap: 4-12cm, bell-shaped, smooth, convex up to almost flat, sometimes with a small wide central knob, margin radial grooved, because skin is transparent; colour changed from light brown up to greyish-brown or brown; often concentric colouring. Young cap shape between oval and cone and it often has dirty remnant of veil at the top (minor old cap has).
Flesh is white. Gills free, close to almost distant, white up to dull brown. Odour is weak and pleasant.
Stalk: 8-16cm long, 0.6-2cm thick, enlarged weakly down; white up to dull brownish-white or dull greyish-brown when old. Lower part of stalk has a sag-like veil. Partial veil is loose and rare.
Habitat: single or small group scattered in pine-tree forest in dry places or along edge in meadows, sometimes near birches among pine-trees.
Mushroom is edible as light-yellow and light-gray kinds.
Season: June-August.

on ground in mixed woods with aspen; cap 3-7 cm, glaborous, ‘silky’ when dry and slippery wet, young/fresh specimens with very small white edge and inrolled, spherical to conical-wavy-lumpy looking; gills notched, white turning pinkish-tan, close; stipe 6-9 cm x 1.5-3 cm broadening towards base, fibrous and peeling where slug-eaten, with no scurfiness or ring remnant observed; odor unremarkable, taste unpleasant to mildly acrid. spore print – pinkish brown Comments: I’ve tried to ID this puppy several times over the years, ending with different species guesses. Kuo suggest insigne in presence of aspen; several MO observations from Ontario farther east than MN; but lacks scurfiness on stipe apex. A lovely mushroom.

results.notes: Several large specimens fruiting in the ground hidden under brush; Oak associates. Cap: 11.5 cm. When gills were sliced with a knife, so much milk was produced that it dripped on my deck as I carried the cap to the railing for a photo. Stipe: 7 cm. X 1.8 cm., tapering sharply toward base. White milk discolors cap, stem, and gills a reddish-brown. KOH was negative. No detectable odor. Obtained a creamy/pale-yellowish spore print.
